text: Banjo maestro Barney McKenna of The Dubliners dies in his home in Howth, Co Dublin. At the age of 72.
Legendary singer Ronnie Drew dies at the age of 73. He was a founder member of The Dubliners. Thanks for the music Ronnie. We love you!
Irish folk music and folklore collector, singer and social historian Tom Munnelly dies in Miltown Malbay, Co. Clare, aged 63.
Tommy Makem, known as The Bard of Armagh, dies following a lengthy battle with lung cancer at his home in Dover, New Hampshire.
Johnny Moynihan and Andy Irvine do a one-off gig as Sweeney's Men in Rostrevor, Co. Down, with Paul Brady deputising for Joe Dolan who was unwell.
Mícheál Ó Domhnaill, former member of Skara Brae, Bothy Band and Relativity, is buried in his hometown of Kells, County Meath.
Mícheál Ó Domhnaill, former member of Skara Brae, Bothy Band and Relativity, dies in his home in Dublin at the age of 54.
Irish traditional singer and song collector Frank Harte dies at the age of 72. He was widely known for his distinctive singing in the Dublin accent.
Cyril Tawney, one of the fathers of the folk revival in the UK, dies at the age of 74. He wrote "Sally Free And Easy", a song recorded by Bob Dylan.
Belfast born violin player Sean McGuire dies at the age of 78. He was held in awe by traditional musicians as one of the most gifted performers.
One of Scotland's finest fiddlers and composers, Johnny Cunningham, dies at the age of 46 after suffering a heart attack at his home on Manhattan.
East Galway fiddler Lucy Farr dies. Spending most of her life in London, she was from the 1950's a regular player at The Bedford Arms pub.
Richard Harris, the actor whose roles ranged from King Arthur in Camelot to Headmaster Dumbledore in the Harry Potter movies, dies. He was 72.
The Chieftains multi-instrumentalist Derek Bell dies suddenly after undergoing minor surgery in a Phoenix hospital.
The first Johnny Keenan Banjo Festival is held in Longford. Celebrating the memory of the traditional musician from Dublin who died in March 2000.
The Kilkenny Cats beat the Clare Banners and collect their 27th All-Ireland hurling title in front of 76,254 fans at Croke Park.
Singer and banjo player Bobby Clancy dies from Cystic fibrosis. He was one of the famed Clancy Brothers.
Alan Lomax dies. Called "The Father of the American folk music revival", for his work as an ethnomusicologist, record producer and network radio host.
Euro notes and coins are introduced in Ireland. Irish coins and banknotes are being withdrawn from circulation by February 9.
Singer and guitarist Tony Cuffe dies in Arlington, Massachusetts, USA. A former member of, among others, Ossian. Tony was only 47.
The burial ceremony for former King Laoghaire guitarist Leif Andersson is held at the Church of Vänersborg. A memorable, musical event. R.I.P. Leif.
Former King Laoghaire guitarist Leif Andersson dies. He was one of the founding members of the band. Leif was 38 years old. RIP.
Former King Laoghaire bass player Henrik Wüst gets married to his Nadine. Hey, Skinny, don't forget to buy her something nice today!!!
The best of the Champion Céilí Bands over the years gather for one massive performance at Fleadh Nua in the West County Hotel, Ennis, County Clare.
Thousands flock to Kilrush for the 40th anniversary of Ireland's only concertina-based festival held every year in memory of Elizabeth Crotty.
Michael Flatley's Lord of the Dance extravaganza is staged at Belfast's historic Stormont Castle.
Clare fiddler Bobby Casey dies. Living most of his life in London, he performed at the first Willie Clancy Summer School in 1973 in Miltown Malbay.
Saint Patrick's Day is the formal national holiday on which Ireland celebrates its patron saint, Saint Patrick. HAPPY ST. PATS TO YOU ALL!!!
Renegade spy David Shayler alleges that British intelligence services believe John Lennon secretly helped to fund the IRA.
Peter Mandelson suspends the 72-day-old power-sharing executive and restores direct rule to Northern Ireland from Westminster.
The Northern Ireland Executive, set up under the Belfast Agreement, take over responsibility of government in the North.
History comes alive at Phoenix Park as beating of the Millennium Drum signals the beginning of a week long celebration of Irish history and heritage.
Irish Government abandon all plans to transform Great Blasket Island into a State Park and the 1,132 acre island is to remain in private ownership.
The reconvened Scottish Parliament is officially opened. The opening see the Queen transfer full constitutional powers to Edinburgh.
Singer Sinéad O'Connor becomes Mother Bernadette Mary at a ceremony staged by the breakaway Latin Tridentine church in Lourdes.
Derek Hill becomes the eleventh honorary citizen of Ireland. Hill is best-known for donating his home and the adjoining Glebe Gallery to the State.
After 5,000 Orangemen accompany a march through Portadown, Sinn Féin accuses Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble of encouraging the Order.
Paddy Clancy, founder member of the Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem, dies at his home in Carrick-on-Suir, Co. Tipperary, at the age of 76.
Dance superstar Michael Flatley and his former manager John Reid dramatically settle their multi-million pound court wrangle.
British troops are withdrawn from the streets of Belfast in response to the ongoing republican and loyalist cease-fires.
Near the scene of the explosion, US President Bill Clinton and British Premier Tony Blair unveil a plaque in memory of the Omagh bombing victims.
The Real IRA and the 32 County Sovereignty Committee are to be placed on an international terrorist list by the US Government.
First all-Ireland poll since the general election of 1918 see the Good Friday Agreement approved by 71.2% of voters in the North and 95% in the South.
The Good Friday Agreement is signed in Belfast by the British and Irish Governments and most Northern Irish political parties.
Fiddler Bobby Campbell dies at the age of 55. He was a member of The Exiles, The Emmettones, The New Deal String Band among others.
Julia Clifford dies at the age of 82. She is recorded with her brother Denis Murphy on "The Star Above The Garter". Julia is buried in Norfolk.
Jimmy Kennedy, composer of popular songs including Did Your Mother Come from Ireland, is inducted posthumously into the Songwriters Hall of Fame.
Former Silly Wizard, Phil Cunningham's orchestral work 'The Highlands & Islands Suite' is premiered at The Glasgow Royal Concert Hall.
The IRA ends its ceasefire by bombing South Quays Rail station. No one's injured on the railway station but 2 persons are killed some distance away.
Scottish folk singer Hamish Imlach dies at the age of 55. Born in India by Scottish parents, he lived in Australia before coming to Scotland at 13.
After 26 years of shows by some of Ireland's top artists, Dublin's Baggot Inn hosts its final live concert performance.
The Times obituary describe guitarist Rory Gallagher as "an uncompromisingly serious musician" and "a courageously honest performer".
Irish guitarist Rory Gallagher dies in London from complications following a liver transplant. He was only 47 years old.
Sir Patrick Mayhew sets out the conditions for Sinn Féin to join all-party talks, including 'the actual decommissioning of some arms'.
Micho Russell is killed in a car crash. The last weekend in February each year the Micho Russell Memorial Weekend is held in his hometown of Doolin.
Irish Taoiseach Albert Reynolds and John Major announce that Sinn Féin can join talks on the future of Northern Ireland if the IRA renounces violence.
The song Barley And Grape Rag is recorded in a London studio by The Dubliners and guitarist Rory Gallagher. It appears on 30 Years A'Greying.
An IRA bomb destroys the Baltic Exchange building in London's financial district. Three people are killed and 80 are injured.
Mary Robinson becomes the first Irish President to visit Belfast. She was the first female President of Ireland, serving from 1990 to 1997.
An RUC officer in Belfast kills three people in a Sinn Féin office before committing suicide. He gained entry to the office posing as a journalist.
The Provisional IRA launch a mortar through the roof of a white van parked in Whitehall. The mortar explodes in the back garden of 10 Downing Street
Tom Clancy, founder member of the Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem, dies in Cork after some time of ill health.
Scottish folk musician and songwriter, Roy Williamson, dies. He was one of the famous duo, the Corries, along with Ronnie Browne.
Writer Samuel Beckett dies in Paris, France. Beckett, known for plays like Waiting For Godot, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1969.
Margaret Barry, "The Bard" or "The Queen Of The Irish Tinkers", dies. She is buried at St Colman's Laurencetown, Co Down two days later.
British folk singer, songwriter, socialist, actor, poet, playwright, and record producer Ewan MacColl (James Henry Miller) dies at the age of 74.
The Irish Republican Army (IRA) explodes a bomb at the Deal Barracks, Kent, Northern Ireland. 11 British soldiers are killed.
Songwriter and playwright Dominic Behan dies in his Glasgow home. He's the author of songs like The Patriot Game and Liverpool Lou.
The first Aer Lingus flight with an all-female crew, led by Captain Gráinne Cronin and Co-Pilot Elaine Egan, goes from Dublin to Shannon.
Ciarán Bourke, of The Dubliners, dies following years of ill health. He suffered a brain haemorrhage while on stage with the group in 1974.
Three unarmed IRA members are shot dead by the Special Air Service in Gibraltar. SAS claim they feared the three were about to detonate a bomb.
The Pogues song Fairytale of New York, a duet between lead singer Shane MacGowan and Kirsty MacColl, reach no. 2 in the British charts.
During the annual Remembrance Day ceremony, an IRA bomb kills 11 people and 63 are injured, at the War Memorial in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh.
Hurricane Charley hit Ireland. The Dodder and Dargle Rivers overflow their banks, flooding over 400 businesses and homes.
After a bitter campaign, the referendum to legalize divorce in Ireland is defeated, 60.8 percent to 36.5 percent.
Bassist and song writer Phil Lynott dies from heart failure and pneumonia after years of drug abuse.
Garret FitzGerald, prime minister of Ireland between 1982-87, signs the Anglo-Irish Agreement with Margaret Thatcher.
The IRA kills five people in a bomb attack at the Grand Hotel, Brighton, during the Conservative Party conference.
Seosamh Ó hÉanaí, the great Sean-nós singer from Connemara, dies. One of Luke Kelly's major influences, his English name was Joe Heaney.
Luke Kelly dies in his place of birth, Dublin. In 1980 he had been diagnosed with a brain tumour. The tumour was removed, but Luke fell ill again.
A bomb planted by members of the Provisional IRA outside Harrods in London kills 6 people and injures at least 90 others.
Live in Carré is recorded in Amsterdam. The last recording of Luke Kelly with The Dubliners. Luke died in 1984. The album was released in 1985.
Thin Lizzy split after 13 turbulent years which saw them hailed as one of the world's greatest rock bands.
Traditional Irish singer Sarah Makem from Keady, Co Armagh, dies at the age of 82. She was the mother of singer Tommy Makem.
FitzGerald succeeds Haughey as Taoiseach. General election in the Republic on 24 November lead to a Fine Gael-Labour coalition government.
The INLA (Irish National Liberation Army) kills 17 people in a bomb attack at the Droppin Well Inn, Ballykelly, Co. Derry.
Patrick Hillery is installed as President of Ireland for a second term. He was President from 1976 to 1990 and belonged to the Fianna Fáil party.
Séamus Ennis, uilleann piper, broadcaster and folklore and music collector dies at his home in Naul at the age of 63.
The Ireland rugby team wins the Triple Crown Ireland for the first time since 1949 by beating Scotland 21-12, having already beaten Wales and England.
The use of corporal punishment is banned in Irish schools. A committee was established to consider the question of discipline in schools.
Christy Brown, the handicapped Dublin author, who learned to type with his left foot dies aged 49. The film My Left Foot tells the story of his life.
Garret FitzGerald becomes the seventh Taoiseach (prime minister) of the Republic of Ireland when he takes over from Charles J. Haughey.
Bobby Sands dies in prison after a 66 day hunger strike. The 27-year-old republican spent his last days on a water bed to protect his fragile bones.
Imprisoned IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands is elected to Westminster as the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone.
Bobby Sands, who had served five years of a fourteen year sentence for possessing a gun begin his hunger strike.
Prisoners in Armagh and Long Kesh end hunger strike on promises of political status. The promises are not kept.
Haughey and Thatcher meet in Dublin, and agree to consider 'the totality of relationships within these islands'.
Footballer Robbie Keane is born. In October 1998 he became the youngest player to score for Ireland eclipsing Johnny Giles' 30-year-old record.
The Derrynaflan Hoard, consisting of a silver chalice, silver paten, paten stand and a decorated bronze strainer-ladle from the 8th century, is found.
Donegal fiddler and composer John Doherty dies. He was a native Irish speaker and carried a large store of folklore and stories.
Kevin Keegan, accordion maestro, dies in San Francisco. His playing can be heard on the CD "The Music Of Kevin Keegan". He is buried in Co. Galway.
A rally of twelve to fifteen thousand Peace People from both north and south takes place at the new bridge over the Boyne at Drogheda.
The founders of the Peace Movement, Mairéad Corrigan and Betty Williams, are awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
Éamon de Valera dies. He was one of the leaders of Ireland's struggle for independence from Britain in the early 20th Century.
Mother Mary Martin, founder of the Medical Missionaries of Mary, dies in Drogheda. The Medical Missionaries of Mary first came to America in 1950.
Michael Gaughan dies on the sixty-fifth day of his hunger strike at Parkhurst Prison. The first hunger strike death of the contemporary troubles.
Footballer Liam Brady scores his first goal in the English League against Queens Park Rangers. Arsenal, the club for which he was playing, drew 1-1.
Kerry fiddler Denis Murphy dies at the age of 63. Denis was a regular at the Sunday music session at Dan O'Connells pub in Knocknagree.
Legendary box player Joe Cooley dies in Ireland. He is buried in Killtomas graveyard where still is heard Sean Leahey's "Farewell to Joe Cooley".
Tripartite talks on Northern Ireland ends in an historic agreement, the Sunningdale Agreement, to set up a power sharing Council of Ireland.
Tony MacMahon, knowing that box player Joe Cooley was dying from cancer, arranged the famous recording session in Lahiffe's Bar in Peterswell.
Irish footballler Liam Brady makes his leagie debut against Birmingham City. He was playing for Arsenal FC and he was 17 years old. Arsenal won 1-0.
Willie Clancy, legendary uilleann piper from Miltown Malbay, dies suddenly in a Galway hospital. Every year his memory is celebrated in his hometown.
Ireland joins the European Economic Community. The main reason for this was to gain access to new markets, and to avoid future reliance on the UK.
Thin Lizzy return from UK to Ireland for a Christmas tour with Whiskey In The Jar at no. 1 in the Irish charts.
The Special Criminal Court is established in response to the escalation of violence in the North and associated paramilitary activity in the South.
Cecil Day-Lewis, Irish-born poet, as well as Poet Laureate for Britain between 1968 to 1972, dies in Hadley Wood, Hertfordshire, England.
Bloody Sunday. Twenty-seven people are shot by British soldiers during a riot that followed a civil rights march in the Bogside area of Derry.
Padraic Colum, poet, playwright and founder of the Irish National Theatre dies. His contributions to the early Irish Dramatic Movement were important.
Jimmy MacBeath, one of Britain's finest traditional singers and one of the major influences on the Scottish folk song revival, dies.
RTÉ, Raidió Teilifís Éireann, bans several patriotic ballads including Dublin In The Green and The Patriot Game.
Seán Ó Riada dies. Guided by his vision, traditional music changed radically, and became accessible to a modern Irish audience.
Henrik Larsson, Swedish international and Celtic football legend, is born in Helsingborg. He played in the World Cup finals of 1994, 2002 and 2006.
Manchester United and Ireland midfielder Roy Keane is born. He started his career with Cobh Ramblers before Brian Clough took him to Nottingham Forest.
Footballer Roy Keane is born. He made his full senior debut against Chile in 1991, and went on to play for the Republic of Ireland in the 1994 World Cup finals.
The Gaelic Athletic Association, guardians of the native Irish games Hurling and Gaelic Football, lifts its ban on members playing "foreign" sports.
The Ibrox Stadium disaster, when 66 supporters were killed on stairway 13. This led to the rebuilding of an all seater stadium.
Leo Rowsome, the 'King of the Irish pipers', dies suddenly in Co. Sligo while adjudicating in the 'Fiddler of Dooney' fiddleplaying championship.
King Laoghaire guitarist Björn Lindgren is born in Borås, Sweden. He's been a member of the band since 1996. Happy Birthday, Björn!
Former King Laoghaire bass player Henrik Wüst is born. He used to play with us between 1993-1994 and 1996-2005. Happy Birthday, Skinny!
King Laoghaire accordion player Peo Linnervik is born. Happy birthday Peo! And don't do anything we wouldn't do...
Sinn Féin, mirroring the December split in the IRA, are divided into two wings - the more marxist Officials and the more hardline Provisionals.
Sonia O'Sullivan is born. She became the first Irish woman to break a world track record by running the 5,000 m on 15:17.28 in 1991.
The Irish Finance Act exempts people considered to have written works of cultural or artistic merit from income tax on money earned by the works.
Rioting breaks out in Derry and Dungiven, resulting in the first death related to the Northern Ireland disturbances.
Ireland enacts exemption from income tax under certain circumstances for artists, writers, composers and sculptors.
Sharon Shannon is born in Ruan, Co Clare. She is best known for her work with the accordion and for her fiddle technique.
The Black Velvet Band by The Dubliners enters the British charts. The group had also had a hit with Seven Drunken Nights which went to no 5.
King Laoghaire tin whistle and banjo player Per Andersson is born. He relocated after living 10 years in Los Angeles to become a fulltime member.
Christy Moore makes his first performance as a professional folksinger at The Wellgreen Folk Club in Manchester. He is paid £6.
The Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association is founded in Belfast, as a response to four decades of Unionist discrimination against Catholics.
King Laoghaire and Dún Aengus singer and guitarist Martin Rahmberg is born. He is a founding member of the group. Happy Birthday and a Happy New Year, Rahmed.
Irish novelist and poet Brian O'Nolan, aka Flann O'Brien, aka Myles na gCopaleen, dies at the age of 54.

Nelson's Pillar is blown up by persons unknown to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the 1916 rising. It now lies in a heap in County Wicklow. The song Nelson's Farewell is a comical observation of the event.
Death of Irish statesman and Sinn Féin member William Thomas Cosgrave. Also the first President of the Irish Free State.
Footballer Norman Whiteside is born. In 1982 he became the youngest player, at 17 years and 42 days, to take part in the World Cup finals.
Irish actor and comedian Jimmy O'Dea dies at the age of 65. Together with Harry O'Donovan he created his most famous character - Biddy Mulligan.
The Dubliners plays a concert at the Cecil Sharpe House in London. The concert is being recorded and released in 1965 as "The Dubliners in concert".
Bobby Lynch makes his only recording appearance with The Dubliners, when the gig the band plays at the Cecil Sharpe House is being recorded.
King Laoghaire singer and tenor banjo player, Peter Andersson is born. He is a founding member of the group. Happy Birthday, Pete!
Birth of Peter Andersson, the second best banjo player, singer as well as the hairiest member of King Laoghaire.
Divis Street riots follow Ian Paisley's insistence that the RUC remove the Tricolour from a window at Sinn Féin's Belfast headquarters.
Playwright Sean O'Casey dies in England aged 84 due to a heart attack. He is known for his almost photographically real pictures of Irish tenement life.
Writer Brendan Behan dies. A newspaper described his funeral as the biggest since those of Michael Collins and Charles Stewart Parnell.
President John F Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, Texas at 12:30 PM Central time. He was on a campaign and support trip through the Southern US.
Irish poet and playwright Louis MacNeice dies aged 45. He was part of the generation of "thirties poets" which included W H Auden and Cecil Day-Lewis.
Fiddler and banjo player Cathal Hayden is born in the village of Rock, County Tyrone. He's been a member of Arcady and Four Men And A Dog.
IRA 'border campaign' is called off, having fizzled out in any case. It had claimed 18 lives: 8 IRA members, 4 supporters and 6 RUC members.
Footballer Ronnie Whelan is born. In his career at Liverpool he played 492 games, scoring 73 goals. He won 53 caps for the Republic of Ireland, scoring three goals.
John F Kennedy is inaugurated as President with his famous words: "ask not what your country can do for you – ask what you can do for your country".
Concertina player Elizabeth "Mrs" Crotty dies. She is buried in Shanakyle cemetery, about a mile west of Kilrush.
Kenneth Branagh, actor/director, is born in Belfast. He has directed and starred in such films as Henry V, Peter's Friends and Hamlet.
Irish singer Frances Black is born in Dublin. She came to prominence in the 1980s when she began to play with her brothers' band, The Black Family.
Goalkeeper Packie Bonner, who became a folk hero of Irish sport following his penalty save against Romania in the World Cup finals of 1990, is born.
A broadcasting authority, Radio Éireann, is established to conduct national radio and television services.
The P&O liner Canberra, with a gross tonnage of 45,733, is launched at Harland and Wolff in Belfast. She could take 3949 passengers and a crew of 803.
Legendary scottish musician Phil Cunningham is born in Edinburgh. Phil was a member of Silly Wizard and later formed a succesful duo with Aly Bain.
Éamon de Valera, one of the leaders of the 1916 rebellion, is elected President of the Republic, he is installed on 25 June.
John Whelan is born in Luton. He's won six All-Britain and seven All-Ireland button accordion championships. John is a US resident since 1980.
Mick McCarthy (Barnsley, Manchester City, Celtic, Olympic Lyon, Millwall and Republic of Ireland footballer; Millwall and Ireland manager) is born.
The Pogues tin whistle player Spider Stacy is born in Eastbourne. He had played in The Millwall Chainsaws, a prototype of what should become The Pogues.
Irish singer and actress Maura O'Connell is born in Ennis, Co Clare. She's known for her contemporary interpretation of Irish folk songs.
Football player and manager David O'Leary is born. At Arsenal for 18 years, he won two League Championships, two FA Cups and two League Cups.
Singer Shane MacGowan is born in Kent, England where his parents were visiting relatives. He spent his first six years in northwest Tipperary.
Shamrock Rovers become the first League of Ireland team to play in the European Cup — they lose 6-0 to Manchester United.
Johnny Cunningham, legendary fiddler with among others Silly Wizard, Relativity, Celtic Fiddle Festival and The Raindogs, is born in Portobello, Scotland.
The Pogues guitarist Philip Chevron is born in Dublin. He moved to London with Irish punk band The Radiators in the seventies.
Footballer Mark Lawrenson is born. With Liverpool he made 332 appearances and scored 17 goals. He also won 38 caps for the Republic of Ireland.
Alan Simpson, co-director of The Rose Tattoo at the Pike Theatre, Dublin, is arrested and jailed overnight because a condom appeared on stage.
Martin Hadden, former bass player with Silly Wizard, is born in Aberdeen, Scotland. Martin joined the group in 1976.
Jack Butler Yeats, painter and poet, dies. He began his career as an illustrator and produced his first oils in 1915, choosing literary subjects.
Tens of thousands attend Sean South's funeral in Limerick. South had been killed in a IRA attack on an RUC barracks on New Year's Day.
IRA members Fergal O'Hanlon and Sean South are killed in an attack on Brookeborough Barracks, Co. Fermanagh, on New Year's Day.
Fiddler Liz Carroll is born in Chicago. Liz started to learn violin at the age of nine. She won the senior All-Ireland title at the age of 19.
Irish striker Frank Stapleton is born. He signed for Arsenal in 1972 and made his league debut the following year. Frank won 71 caps for his country.
Gaelic footballer and soccer player Kevin Moran is born. He is the only person to win both All-Ireland senior football medals and FA cup medals.
Ireland international Liam Brady is born. Blessed with one of the sweetest left-foots in football, Liam represented Arsenal and West Ham.
Ian Bruce is born in Glasgow to a Scottish father and a Welsh mother. He's one of the most popular singer-songwriters on the British folk scene.
Belfast-born Ruby Murray has two singles in the British top 20. She also had five top 20 songs at one time, a feat only beaten by Madonna.
The Pogues banjo player and song writer Jem Finer is born. He co-wrote Fairytale of New York with fellow pogue Shane MacGowan.
Singer Mary Black is born in Dublin. Once a member of De Dannan. She is well-known for her interpretation of both folk and contemporary material.
Fiddler Jerry Holland is born in Brockton, Massachusetts. He was much influenced by the music of the large expatriate Cape Breton community in Boston.
The Pogues accordion player James Fearnley is born. He had played together with Shane MacGowan in London pop/punk band The Nips.
Limerick man Michael Manning (25) is the last man to be judicially executed at Mountjoy jail for the murder of an elderly nurse.
Singer and guitarist Tony Cuffe is born in Greenock, Scotland. He was a member of scottish groups Alba, Jock Tamson's Bairns and Ossian.
Eugene O'Neill, the only American playwright ever to receive the Nobel Prize in Literature, dies in Boston, MA.
The Pogues drummer Andrew Ranken is born in Ladbroke Grove, London. He appeared on all of The Pogues official recordings.
Dolores Keane is born in Sylane, Co Galway. She's a founding member of the group De Dannan. She has also had a very successful solo career.
Cinemas in Dublin decide not to show Queen Elizabeth's coronation. There are fears that a screening would lead to widespread damage to the cinemas.
Bord Fáilte, the Irish Tourist Board, is set up "to make further and better provision for the encouragement and development of the tourist traffic".
Actor Liam Neeson (William John Neeson) is born in Ballymena, Co Antrim. He made his professional acting debut at the Belfast Lyric Players' Theater.
Footballer Martin O'Neill is born in Kilrea, Co. Derry. As a player he represented Nottingham Forest's European Cup winning team in 1979.
The Arts Council is established in the Republic, to stimulate public interest in and promote the knowledge, appreciation and practice of the arts.
Ian Paisley co-founds and becomes moderator of his own church, the Free Presbyterian Church of Ulster.
Kenny Dalglish, arguably Scotland's greatest football player of all time, is born. He started his career at Celtic before moving to Liverpool.
Irish dramatist, literary critic and socialist spokesman George Bernard Shaw dies. In 1925 he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Danny McGrain, Celtic and Scotland defender, is born in Glasgow. He played for the Scottish national side in the 1974 and 1982 World Cups.
Legendary travelling piper Johnny Doran dies in a St Vincent's Hospital, Athy, Co Kildare. He is buried in Rathnew cemetery in Co Wicklow.
Legendary travelling piper Johnny Doran is re-admitted to hospital due to injuries he recieved when a wall collapsed over his caravan in 1948.
Thin Lizzy bass player and songwriter Phil Lynott is born in Birmingham, England of an Irish mother and a Brazilian father.
Footballer Don Givens is born. In 56 international appearances for the Republic of Ireland over 13 years, he scored 18 goals.
The first President of Ireland, Douglas Hyde, dies. In April 1940 he had suffered a massive stroke and became paralysed and confined to a wheelchair.
Éire formally becomes the Republic of Ireland. As a republic, its membership of the British Commonwealth lapsed.
The Belfast Celtic Football Club is forced out of competition after the dramatic game against Belfast rivals Linfield.
Rory Gallagher is born in Ballyshannon, Co Donegal. The world known guitarist spent his youth and made his first musical explorations in Cork.
Travelling piper Johnny Doran is paralysed from the waist down when a wall collapse over his caravan. He dies two years later in a Kildare hospital.
Terry Woods, former member of among others Sweeney's Men, Steeleye Span and The Pogues, is born in Dublin.
Dónal Lunny, musician and producer, is born. He's been a member of influental groups such as Planxty, Bothy Band and Moving Hearts.
James Larkin dies aged 72. He was a union leader and politician who started two left-wing newspapers, "The Irish Worker" and "Irish Workers' Voice".
Flute player Matt Molloy is born in Ballaghaderreen, Roscommon. He has been a member of The Bothy Band, Planxty and The Chieftains.
Singer Gilbert O'Sullivan is born in Waterford as Raymond Edward O'Sullivan. Popular songs from his pen include "Alone Again (Naturally)".
Guitarist and producer Eamonn Campbell is born in Drogheda, Co Louth. He joined The Dubliners as a full time member in 1987.
Seán Keane, fiddler with The Chieftains, is born in Dublin. He joined The Chieftains in 1968 upon invitation by Paddy Moloney.
George Best, one of the most remarkable football players the world has seen, despite his short career on the field, is born in Belfast.
Uilleann piper and pipe maker Eugene Lambe is born in Malahide, Co Dublin. He started making uilleann pipes when a student in college around 1968.
Douglas Hyde, first President of Ireland, resigns due to ill-health. Hyde, with his handlebar moustache and warm personality was a popular president.
Legendary goalkeeper Pat Jennings is born. He is Northern Ireland's most capped player, with 119 (then a world record) earned between 1964 and 1986.
Legendary singer Christy Moore, once a member of Irish folk group Planxty, is born. But he is probably best known for his solo work.
Uilleann piper Liam O'Flynn is born in Kill, Co Kildare. He became a founder member of Planxty in both of its incarnations.
The Chieftains singer and bodhrán player Kevin Conneff is born in Donore, Dublin. He was very much influenced by Sean-nós singing.
Irish fiddler Michael Coleman dies in Knickerbocker Hospital, Manhattan aged 54 years. He is buried in St. Raymond's Cemetry, The Bronx, New York.
Ralph McTell, singer and writer of songs such as From Clare To Here and Streets Of London, is born in Farnborough, Kent, England.
Traditional Irish musician and scholar Mick Moloney is born in Limerick. He gained early fame as a member of The Johnstons and The Emmet Spiceland.
Jim McCann, singer and guitar player, is born. He was a member of The Dubliners between 1974 and 1979. Jim's appeared as special guest after leaving.
Eric Bogle is born in Peebles, Scotland. Emigrating to Australia in 1969, he is known for writing songs like The Band Played Waltzing Matilda and Green Fields of France.
Frank Ryan, dies in a sanatorium in Dresden. In 1936, he led 200 Irishmen to fight in the International Brigades for the Republic against Franco.
Irish folk music and folklore collector, singer and social historian, Tom Munnelly, is born in Dublin.
Footballer, journalist and broadcaster Eamonn Dunphy is born. He won 23 Republic of Ireland caps between 1966 and 1977.
Peadar Kearney, who in 1907 wrote the lyrics to the Irish national anthem The Soldier's Song (Amhrán na bhFiann), dies in Inchicore.
Fiddler Bobby Campbell is born. He was a member of The Exiles who were an important influence during the formative years of the folk revival.
Andy Irvine is born in London. As well as a succesful solo career he has been a member of Sweeney's Men, Planxty, Patrick Street and Mozaik.
Composer and producer Phil Coulter is born. He grew up in Derry, and is famous for writing the song The Town I Loved So Well about his hometown.
US troops arrive in Northern Ireland. De Valera protests - 300,000 troops will be stationed there between 1942 and 1945.
Dublin's North Strand is hit by a 500 pound German bomb, killing more than 30 and injuring 90. More bombs fall on Summerhill and the Phoenix Park.
Irish writer James Joyce dies in Zürich, Switzerland, from a perforated duodenal ulcer. He dies at age fifty eight and is buried in Zürich.
Luke Kelly, singer and founding member of The Dubliners, is born. He suggested the name after reading the James Joyce novel. Luke died in 1984.
Legendary footballer Johnny Giles is born. He was player-manager of the Irish national team between 1973 and 1980.
Irish singer Johnny Moynihan is born in Phibsboro, Dublin. He is often credited as being responsible for introducing the bouzouki into Irish music.
Footballer Denis Law is born. He managed to score 30 times in only 55 international appearances representing Scotland.
Scottish folk singer Hamish Imlach is born in Calcutta, India. He was a larger-than-life singer and humorist who toured up until his death in 1996.
Joe Burke is born. He's steeped in the tradition of the Loughrea, Co Galway area. Joe's one of the most influental accordionists in Ireland.
Barney McKenna, tenor banjo player with The Dubliners, is born. He is probably the main reason for the tenor banjo being accepted as an Irish instrument.
Scottish folk singer Archie Fisher is born in Glasgow. He's presented Radio Scotland's weekly "Travelling Folk" programme since 1983.
Garech a Brún, founder of Claddagh Records, music publisher and world-traveller, is born in Glenmaroon, Chapelizod, Co. Dublin.
John Sheahan, fiddle and tin whistle player with The Dubliners, is born. He's also known as an accomplished composer of several well known tunes.
The first aircraft lands at Rineanna, later Shannon Airport. By 2000 the airport handled over 2 million passengers annually.
Irish poet, dramatist, mystic and senator, William Butler Yeats, dies. Yeats won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1923.
IRA bombing campaign in Britain commences. On August 25, a bomb in Coventry kills five and injures 70.
Paddy Moloney, founder of The Chieftains, is born in Donnycarney, Dublin. Uilleann pipes, tin whistle and bodhrán are instruments played by him.
Ten young men, potato-pickers from Achill Island, die when a bothy catches fire on a farm at Kirkintilloch, Scotland.
The Scottish playwright and novelist, JM Barrie, dies. He is principally remembered today for his classic children's story, Peter Pan.
Legendary musician Felix J Dolan is born. He played piano on the seminal recording "A Tribute To Michael Coleman" with Andy McGann and Joe Burke.
Northern Irish politician John Hume is born in Derry. He's one of the most important figures in the political history of Northern Ireland.
Birth of Roy Williamson, founding member of the group, the Corries. He wrote the song Flower of Scotland, Scotland's unofficial National Anthem.
Mary Holland, noted journalist of the 1970s and 1980s in Northern Ireland and Scoop of the year award winner in 1994, is born in Dover.
Fianna Fáil declares the IRA to be an illegal organisation following a two-day debate in the Dail. The murderous events of 1935-36 forced a crackdown.
Francis O'Neill dies in Chicago at the age of 87. The man who saved Irish music, he collected and published 1,850 pieces. Remarkable as he was unable to write music!
Derek Bell, multi-instrumentalist with The Chieftains, is born in Belfast. He joined the band full-time in 1974 with the release of Chieftains 4.
Jack Charlton is born. He guided the Republic to the World Cup finals of 1990 and 1994, as well as the 1988 European Champioship finals in Germany.
The Free State bans the sale and import of contraceptives. The age of sexual consent is raised from 16 to 17.
Ciarán Bourke, one of the original Dubliners, is born. He sang and played tin whistle, harmonica and guitar with the group. Ciarán died in 1988.
Ronnie Drew, one of the founding members of The Dubliners, is born. His voice has been described as "the sound of coke being crushed under a door".
The Irish Free State government purchases the copyright of Peadar Kearney's The Soldiers Song which becomes the national anthem.
Frank Harte, traditional Irish singer and song collector, is born in Chapelizod, Co. Dublin. He was a great exponent of the Dublin street ballad.
General Eoin O'Duffy is dismissed as head of the Garda (Police Force), his "National Guard" organisation adopts fascist-style uniform.
Tommy Makem, The Bard of Armagh, is born in Keady, Co. Armagh. He is the writer of songs such as Four Green Fields and Rambles Of Spring among others.
Billy Bingham is born. He managed Northern Ireland in 118 matches up to 1993, guiding them to the World Cup finals in 1982 and 1986.
Folk singer Cyril Tawney is born into a naval family in Gosport, Hampshire. Cyril joined the Royal Navy at 16, serving on submarines for 13 years.
Irish actor Richard Harris is born in Limerick. He started acting when he moved to London in the mid '50s.
Actor Sean Connery, is born in the Fountainbridge area of Edinburgh. To many, he is the one and only James Bond.
The Censorship of Publications Act requires that all books, newspapers and periodicals in the Irish Free State to be submitted for censorship.
Dominic Behan, Irish songwriter, short story writer, novelist and playwright, is born in Dublin. He is the brother of Brendan Behan.
Fiddle master Sean Maguire is born in Belfast. In London he met accordionist Joe Burke. The two were often to tour together joined by Barney McKenna.
The first automatic telephone exchange in Ireland, serving more than 700 customers, is opened at Ship Street, Dublin.
Bobby Clancy is born in Carrick-on-Suir. He performed with the Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem at Bob Dylan's 30th anniversary concert in New York.
At a meeting in Dublin, Éamon de Valera founds a new political party called Fianna Fáil, which became the official opposition in the Dail.
The population of the Free State is shown by a census to be 2,971,992; that of Northern Ireland on the same day is 1,256,561.
Sean O'Casey's The Plough and The Stars evokes a riot at the Abbey Theatre where a number of significant left-wing republicans storms the stage.
Danny Blanchflower is born. Capped 56 times for Northern Ireland, he was captain when they reached the quarter-finals of the World Cup in 1958.
Garret FitzGerald is born. He was the seventh Taoiseach of the Republic of Ireland, heading two coalition governments.
Tom Clancy, founder member of the Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem, is born in Carrick-on-Suir, County Tipperary.
Fiddler Hugh Alan "Buddy" MacMaster is born in Timmins, Ontario. He was introduced to the sounds of the old music through the lilting of his mother.
The first Irish soccer international. A team drawn from the newly formed Football Association of Ireland meets the United States in Dublin.
The Irish poet, playwright and member of the senate, William Butler Yeats, receives the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Cumann na nGaedheal ("Party of the Irish") is formed as a pro-Treaty party. Its first President is William Cosgrave.
James Chichester-Clark, Northern Ireland Prime Minister 1969-1971, is born in Castledawson, Co Derry/Londonderry.
Irish writer Brendan Behan is born in Dublin. He's the author of such works as The Quare Fellow and Borstal Boy.
The United Council of Christian Churches and Religious Communions in Ireland is founded. In 1966 it changed its name to the Irish Council of Churches.
The six counties of Northern Ireland opt out of the Free State.
The Irish Free State comes into existence. Tim Healy is appointed first Governor-General of the Irish Free State.
Popular author and IRA member Robert Erskine Childers is executed by an Irish Free State firing squad for illegally carrying a revolver.
Court martial of Erskine Childers. He had been one of the leaders, with Éamon de Valera, of the IRA rebellion against the Free State leadership.
Michael Collins, en route home through Co Cork, is killed in an ambush. Probably by a ricocheting bullet. He was not yet 32 years old.
Arthur Griffith, the founder and first leader of Sinn Féin, dies suddenly in Dublin. He is buried in Glasnevin Cemetery.
Irish revolutionary Cathal Brugha dies during the Civil War, after being severly wounded on O'Connell Street two days earlier.
The Free State Army takes control of Dublin. Cathal Brugha is wounded and captured in a shoot out with Free State troops on O'Connell Street.
The Provisional Government of the Irish Free State bombards the Four Courts in Dublin, and the Civil War begins.
James Joyce's Ulysses is published in Paris on the author's 40th birthday. Ulysses is regarded as a masterpiece in modern literature.
The provisional Free State government, which many saw as a rejection of the 1916 provisional government, takes over from the British administration.
Michael Collins becomes head of the (Irish) Provisional Government. He also remained Minister for Finance of Griffith's republican administration.
Arthur Griffith is elected Taoiseach of Dáil Éireann after Éamon de Valera steps down. Griffith was the founder of the Sinn Féin party.
Treaty creating the Irish Free State is approved by Dáil Éireann. After a bitter debate in which those backing the deal are accused of treachery.
De Valera resigns as President and is replaced by Arthur Griffith. A Crown-appointed administration under Michael Collins was created also.
The IRA called a truce in July and, after protracted negotiations in London, representants from Dáil Éireann signs a treaty with the British.
James Craig succeeds Edward Carson as Ulster Unionist leader, and later, on the 7th of June becomes the first Prime Minister of Northern Ireland.
The British government announces that any unauthorised person found in possession of arms, ammunition or explosives is liable to be executed.
The Government of Ireland Act enforces the secession of the six Northern Irish counties from the rest of Ireland.
Martial law is declared in Ireland. Black and Tans and Auxiliaries go on a rampage of burning and looting in Cork.
Kevin Barry, an 18 year old member of the Irish Volunteers, is executed by hanging in the Mountjoy Prison, Dublin.
The Lord Mayor of Cork and IRA commander Terence MacSwiney dies in Brixton prison, London, after a hunger strike which lasted for 74 days.
James Larkin gets five to ten years in Sing Sing, on a charge of "advocating force, violence and unlawful means to overthrow the US Government".
The infamous Black and Tans, 800 unemployed ex-servicemen hired as special constables, arrive in Ireland.
John William Alcock and Arthur Whitten Brown land in Clifden, Co. Galway after the first non-stop transatlantic flight, from St John's, Newfoundland.
Séamus Ennis, uilleann piper, broadcaster and folklore and music collector, is born in Jamestown in Finglas, then a rural area of North Co Dublin.
After his escape from Lincoln Jail, Éamon de Valera returns briefly to Ireland and is elected President of the Dail.
Dáil Éireann meets for the first time and elects Éamon de Valera as the first President of Ireland.
Sinn Féin MP's gather in Dublin to proclaim the Irish Republic under the President of Dáil Éireann, Éamon de Valera.
First Dáil Éireann elected when Sinn Féin wins 73 of Ireland's 105 Parliamentary seats at Westminster.
Uilleann piper Willie Clancy from Miltown Malbay is born. Every year in early July, his hometown in West Clare celebrate his memory. He died in 1973.
De Valera is arrested and deported for internment to England after leading the succesful opposition to the proposition to extend conscription.
James Larkin establish the James Connolly Socialist Club in New York. It became the centre of left-wing activities among the Irish socialists in NY.
Concertina player Gerdie Cummane is born in Ballyknock, Co Clare. He started playing in 1926, learning from his father's humming of tunes.
American president John Fitzgerald Kennedy is born in Brookline in the Boston, Massachusetts, metropolitan area.
Margaret Barry is born in Cork. A legendary folk figure renowned for her singing with her banjo at fairs on both sides of the Irish border.
"O'Neil of the Glen", the first production released by the Film Company of Ireland, premiers at Dublin's Bohemian Theatre.
James Connolly is executed. Connolly served in the General Post Office during the Easter Rising and was severely wounded.
Joseph Mary Plunkett is executed. The same morning in the courtyard of Kilmainham jail he married his fiance, Grace Gifford, in the jail's chapel.
Pádraic H Pearse and fourteen others are executed by firing squad without trial for leading the insurrection in Dublin.
The Easter Rising ends as the rebels are shelled into submission. Hundreds are killed and wounded, including civilians caught in the crossfire.
The post office building is under violent attack. Recognising the futility of further resistance, Pearse surrenders unconditionally in the afternoon.
Francis Sheehy Skeffington is shot dead in Portobello Barracks after attempting to stop the looting associated with the Easter Rising.
The Easter Rising marks the most famous attempt by militant republicans to seize control of Ireland and force independence from the United Kingdom.
The Aud, en route from Germany with 20,000 rifles for the Volunteers, is captured by the British Navy and forced to sail towards Cork Harbour.
British folk singer, songwriter, socialist, actor, poet, playwright, and record producer Ewan MacColl is born in Broughton, Salford, Lancashire.
Alan Lomax, among other things a musicologist, author, disc jockey, singer, filmmaker, concert and recording producer and television host, is born.
Erskine Childers sails into Howth in his own yacht bearing 900 rifles and 14,000 rounds of ammunition, supplied from Germany.
Fiddler Julia Clifford is born at Lisheen, Gneevgullia in the Sliabh Luachra area north of Killarney, Co Kerry.
The Britannic, sister ship of the Olympic and the Titanic, is launched in Belfast. She sunk south east of Athens, Greece in 1916 during World War One.
The Irish Volunteers movement is founded. An armed force created in the south to parallel the unionist Ulster Volunteers.
Jim Larkin addresses a crowd in O'Connell Street. His arrest sparks rioting and a baton-charge by the D.M.P. in which several hundred are injured.
Edward Carson, leader of Ulster Unionists, stages the signing of "Southern League and Covenant" against Irish Home Rule.
At 11:40 PM the RMS Titanic struck an iceberg about 400 miles off Newfoundland. She plunged to the bottom, taking more than 1500 people with her.
Third Home Rule Bill introduced. Conservative leader Andrew Bonar Law promises to oppose it and encourages resistance in Ulster.
The RMS Titanic set sail from Southampton on her maiden voyage to New York. At that time, she was the largest and most luxurious ship ever built.
Arguably the most well known ship of all, the RMS Titanic, built by the world renowned Harland and Wolff shipyard leaves Belfast.
Unionists protest when Winston Churchill, a supporter of home rule, visits Belfast. He addresses a crowd in Celtic Park with John Redmond.
Irish novelist and poet Flann O'Brien is born in Strabane, Tyrone. He described and immortalized the Irish love of life and craic in his writing.
Ronald Reagan is born. He is the longest-lived person to have served as President, as well as the oldest elected President (69 years and 349 days).
Kerry fiddler Denis Murphy is born in Lisheen. He made 78 rpm records in the States, both solo and as part of the Ballinmore Ceili Band.
Sir Edward Carson, 1st Lord Carson of Duncairn, is elected leader of the Irish Unionist Parliamentary Party, replacing Walter Long.
Ireland's first cinematographic theatre, the Volta, opens in Dublin, under the management of James Joyce.
John Millington Synge, author of plays such as "Riders to the Sea" and "The Playboy of the Western World", dies at the age of 37.
The Municipal Gallery of Modern Art opens in temporary premises in Harcourt Street, Dublin. The first known public gallery of modern art in the world.
Martin "Junior" Crehan is born in Bonavilla, Mullagh, Co Clare. He's a legendary fiddler, concertina player, singer and composer of many tunes.
Louis MacNeice, poet and classical scholar is born in Belfast. In England, he published many volumes of poetry, criticism and journalistic articles.
Synge's "Playboy of the Western World" is performed at the Abbey Theatre to a hostile audience. Considered to be "pushing the limits of decency".
Michael Cusack (1847-1906), founder of The Gaelic Athletic Association (GAA), dies. Cusack liked to be called "Citizen Cusack".
Nobel Prize in Literature winner Samuel Beckett is born in Foxrock, Dublin. Waiting for Godot is generally regarded as his best-known play.
Over three inches of rain fall in Dublin. North County Wicklow fares even worse with 5.5 inches, causing serious flooding in Bray.
Padraic Fallon, poet and playwright, is born. His verse plays, Diarmuid and Grainne and The Vision of Mac Conglinne, were produced on Radio Éireann.
James Joyce has his first date with Nora Barnacle; ultimately, it became the date on which everything takes place in his masterpiece, Ulysses.
Poet Cecil Day-Lewis is born in Ballintubbert, Co Laois. He is the father of actor Daniel Day-Lewis and television chef Tamasin Day-Lewis.
Seán MacBride, IRA leader, politician, head of Amnesty International, recipient of Nobel and Lenin peace prizes, is born in Paris.
Hampden Park stadium opens in Glasgow as the home of Queen's Park Football Club. It became Scotland's national arena.
The UK's first road race for cars is held between Carlow and Kildare, for the Gordon Bennett Cup. It is won by Mikhael Jenatzy in a Mercedes.
At a public meeting in Belfast, with a crowd of 8,000 attending, Thomas Sloan and others found the Independent Orange Order.
Leo Rowsome, Irish teacher, performer and maker of uilleann pipes, is born in Dublin. Leo founded Cumann na bPíobarí Uilleann in 1936.
Queen Victoria dies. Edward VII accedes to the throne. Dublin Corporation passes a vote of condolence by 30 votes to 22, having initially rejected it.
Irish writer Oscar Wilde dies from meningitis, a serious infectious disease that causes the tissues around the brain and spinal cord to swell.
Sarah Makem, Irish traditional singer, is born. She's also the mother of Tommy Makem, world famous singer with the Clancy Brothers et al.
King Laoghaire bass player and multi-instrumentalist Gjert Magnusson celebrates his birthday. We hope that your canoe is still full!
John Redmond is elected leader of the Irish Parliamentary Party, reunited after being split into several factions in 1890, after Charles Stewart Parnell's demise.
The first number of the weekly paper "The United Irishman" is published. It was founded by Arthur Griffith, nationalist and founder of Sinn Féin.
William O'Brien founds the United Irish League at Westport, which helped to reunite the pro- and anti-Parnell factions of the nationalist movement.
Oscar Wilde is released from prison. After this he spent his last years penniless on the Continent, under the name of Sebastian Melmoth.
Oscar Wilde is convicted of "sodomy and gross indecency" and sentenced to serve two years hard labor in a London prison.
Oscar Wilde is arrested after being formally accused of 'gross indecency', this being little more than a euphemism for an homosexual act.
Oscar Wilde's The Importance of Being Earnest is premiered. It's considered by many to be the finest modern farce in the English language.
The Gaelic League is founded in order to revive the use of the Irish language and foster appreciation of Ireland's Celtic heritage.
Cedric Gibbons is born in Dublin. He was the designer of the coveted Oscar statuette and winner of eleven Academy Awards himself.
Death of Charles Stewart Parnell, champion of tenants rights and co-founder of the Land League; often called the "Uncrowned King of Ireland."
Belfast Celtic, arguably the greatest club in Irish football, is founded in the Falls Road area of Belfast. The club was named after Glasgow Celtic.
Legendary fiddler Michael Coleman is born. By the age of 10 he is an accomplished dancer and violinist and is in demand at local concerts.
Michael Collins, Irish revolutionary leader, Chairman of the Provisional Government and Commander-in-Chief of the National Army, is born.
Eugene O'Neill, the foremost American dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1936, is born in New York.
Joseph Mary Plunkett, Irish patriot, is born. During the 1916 Rising he was one of the signers of the Proclamation of the Irish Republic.
Celtic Football Club is formally constituted in Calton, Glasgow, to alleviate poverty in Glasgow's East End parishes.
Thomas Francis Meagher, General of the US Army, drowns in the Missouri river. He was born in Waterford and had lived a most adventurous life.
92 degrees Fahrenheit (33 Celsius), the highest temperature in Ireland since records began, is recorded at Kilkenny Castle.
Lennox Robinson, playwright and theatrical producer, is born. He was a leading figure in the later stages of the Irish literary renaissance.
Molly Malone reputedly "dies of a fever". The song is a tribute to the memory of a real person who sold cockles and mussels in Dublin.
Elizabeth "Lizzie" Crotty, better known as Mrs Crotty, is born in south west Clare. She's associated with the revival of the concertina in Ireland.
The Irish Loyal and Patriotic Union is formed to oppose Home Rule and maintain the union of Britain and Ireland.
Charles Stewart Parnell turns the first sod for the West Clare Railway, although actual work on the line began on November 3 1884.
Hugh O'Brien is sworn in as Boston's first Irish-born mayor. He carried out various reforms, and was re-elected at the two succeeding elections.
Birth in Co. Down of Harry Ferguson, pioneer of the modern tractor, which today is a priced collectors item.
Irish writer Oscar Wilde marries Constance Lloyd. She was four years younger than Oscar and the daughter of a prominent barrister.
Peadar Kearney is born. He is co-writer of Ireland's National Anthem, Amhrán na bhFiann (Soldier's Song). The song was first published in 1912.
Éamon de Valera is born in Manhattan, New York, to a Spanish father and an Irish mother. He was reared by his grandmother in Ireland.
Lord Frederick Cavendish, British secretary for Ireland, and Thomas Henry Burke, his undersecretary, are assassinated in Phoenix Park, Dublin.
Irish writer James Joyce is born to Mary and John Stanislaus Joyce in Rathgar, a suburb south of Dublin's city centre.
Playwright Padraic Colum is born. He achieved significant recognition away from the theater as a poet, novelist, essayist and children's book author.
After a violent speech against the Land Act, Charles Stewart Parnell is arrested and lodged in Kilmainham jail.
Charles Stewart Parnell delivers his famous speech at Ennis in which he introduces the term for non-violent protest - boycotting.
Playwright Sean O'Casey is born in Dublin. He is known for plays like Juno and the Paycock, The Plough and the Stars, and Shadow of a Gunman.
St. Patrick's Day Parades in Ireland date from the late 19th century, originating in the growing sense of nationalism of the period.
The Irish Rugby Football Union is founded in Dublin. Branches were to be formed in Leinster, Munster and Ulster.
Pádraic Pearse, one of the leaders of the 1916 rebellion, is born in Dublin to an English father and an Irish mother.
Joseph Campbell, poet, is born in Belfast. He is famous for the English words he wrote to the song My Lagan Love.
Irish writer Oliver St. John Gogarty is born. He is the model for the 'stately, plump Buck Mulligan' in James Joyce's Ulysses.
The Intermediate Education Act grants female students the right to participate in public examinations and to enter into careers and professions.
The Black Thursday, four members of the Molly Maguires shackled with chains, walk to the gallows specially constructed to accommodate four people at Mauch Chunk, Carbon County.
The Society for the Preservation of the Irish Language is formed in Dublin (Gaelic revival). In 1851 the number of Irish speakers was 1,524,286, 23% of the population.
The Catalpa arrives off Western Australia. Led by Captain George Anthony, it's mission is to free six Fenian prisoners in Fremantle.
James Larkin, the son of Irish parents, is born in Liverpool. Larkin established his own left-wing newspaper, The Irish Worker.
The Catalpa, fitted and ready, sails out of New Bedford harbor bound for Australia. It's mission is to help Irish political prisoners to escape.
Charles William St John Burgess (Cathal Brugha), Irish revolutionary, is born in Dublin. He had a prominent role in the War of Independence.
The Scottish Football Association is formed. Forming the organisation came from a meeting after the first international match against England.
The first ever international football match is held at West of Scotland Cricket Ground, between Scotland and England in a 0-0 tie.
With the now famous words "Dr Livingstone, I presume?", journalist Henry M Stanley find the missing Scottish missionary David Livingstone.
Irish poet and dramatist John Millington Synge is born in Rathfarnham, County Dublin. He is the author of The Playboy of the Western World.
Arthur Griffith, the founder and first leader of Sinn Féin, is born in Dublin. He served as President of Dáil Éireann from January to August 1922.
Gladstone gives his first speech in the House of Commons on Home Rule. His advocacy of Home Rule was a notable recognition of Irish demands.
Dublin born composer Michael William Balfe dies at his home in Rowney Abbey, Herts. England. He is best known for his opera The Bohemian Girl.
Erskine Childers, novelist, member of the Royal Navy and Irish nationalist is born. He's famous for the classic spy yarn The Riddle of the Sands.
Irish songwriter and novelist Samuel Lover dies. His compositions includes Widow Machree, The Low Backed Car and Molly Bawn.
Countess Markievicz is born in London as Constance Gore-Booth. As a revolutionary she fought for equal rights for women as well as the Irish Republic.
An explosion at Clerkenwell gaol in London, intended to aid in the escape of two Fenians, causes several deaths and injuries.
Fenians Michael Larkin, William Philip Allen and Michael O'Brien, the Manchester Martyrs, are hanged in Manchester, England.
The Fenian rising in Kerry, Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Tipperary and Clare fails. Mainly due to poor organisation and lack of public support.
Thomas Kelly and other Fenians attempts to attack Chester Castle to gain weapons and ammunition. They fail and Kelly and another Fenian are arrested.
The first submarine cable link underneath the Atlantic with a lasting connection is completed. It went from Valentia Island, Co. Kerry to Trinity Bay, Newfoundland.
The Fenian senate deposes founder John O'Mahony as president, replacing him with William R. Roberts, a former New York militia Colonel.
William Butler Yeats, Irish poet, dramatist and mystic, is born. He served as an Irish Senator in the 1920s.
The American Civil War begins. 150,000 Irishmen will serve with the Union forces, and 40,000 with the Confederacy.
John George Adair, alleging a conspiracy amongst his tenants, evicts forty seven families from their smallholdings at Derryveagh, Co. Donegal.
Douglas Hyde, first President of Ireland, is born. His passion for Irish led him to found the Gaelic League in the hope of saving it from extinction.
Scottish writer Arthur Conan Doyle is born in Edinburgh. Doyle is well known for his detective stories with Sherlock Holmes as main character.
New York Archbishop, John Joseph "Dagger" Hughes, lays the corner stone of the new St Patrick's Cathedral on 5th Avenue.
James Stephens forms in Dublin the secret society which become known as the Irish Republican Brotherhood.
George Bernard Shaw is born in Dublin. Shaw was an Irish playright and winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1925.
The last ever Donnybrook Fair, which had been held in Dublin since 1204. The general uproar of the annual event results in its suspension.
The Dublin-Belfast railway line is completed. The final link being the Boyne viaduct, which spanned the Boyne's steep-sided estuary at Drogheda.
Irish writer Oscar Wilde is born. The second son of Sir William Wilde, a doctor, and Jane Francesca Elgee, who wrote revolutionary poems.
The Queen Victoria sinks during a snowstorm outside of Howth Head in the middle of the night. Over 80 people lose their lives.
Thomas Moore, the famous Irish poet, dies. His last years were clouded by the loss of his two sons and by mental illness.
New York is made an archdiocese and Bishop John Joseph "Dagger" Hughes becomes New York's first Archbishop.
Paul Cullen is consecrated Catholic archbishop of Armagh and primate of Ireland. He took a leading part in the national movement of 1850-1852.
Francis O'Neill is born at Tralibane, near Bantry in West Cork. Known as the man who saved Irish music with his collecting and publishing of tunes.
John Mitchel, founder of The United Irishman, is arrested and sentenced to 15 years transportation under the new Treason-Felony Act.
Abraham "Bram" Stoker, author of the book that coined the phrase "undead", Dracula, is born in Dublin, Ireland.
Daniel O'Connell dies in Genoa, while on a journey to Rome. As requested, O'Connell's heart was buried in Rome and his body in Dublin.
The Young Irelanders establish their own Irish Confederation as a purified alternative to the Repeal Association whose basic ideals they still shared.
John Keegan Casey, Fenian, poet and writer of The Rising Of The Moon is born near Mullingar, Co. Westmeath.
Irish statesman, Charles Stewart Parnell, is born in Co. Wicklow. He became one of the most important figures in nineteenth century Ireland and UK.
Michael Moran, also known as Zozimus, the blind storyteller, balladeer and street entertainer, dies in Dublin.
The entire village of Ballinglass, Co. Galway, around 300 people, is evicted in order to turn the land use to grazing.
The Dublin Evening Post reports of the potato blight that have hit Ireland and which ultimately leads to the Great Famine.
Daniel O'Connell is convicted, fined and sentenced to one year's imprisonment. The judgment is reversed by the House of Lords on September 4.
Encouraged by Bishop John Hughes, the Irish Emigrant Society is founded in New York. Out of which the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank later grew.
Father John Hughes is consecrated co-adjutant bishop of New York in the old St Patrick's Cathedral on Mott Street.
Michael William Balfe's opera "The Siege of Rochelle" is first performed at the Drury Lane Theatre in London.
Justin McCarthy, Irish historian and novelist, is born. From 1890 till 1896 he was chairman of the Irish Parliamentary party in succession to Charles Stewart Parnell.
The Wild Colonial Boy is shot dead in Sydney. Contrary to the popular song, his real name was John Donohue, transported from Ireland in 1825.
Hugh O'Brien, the first Catholic Irish-born mayor of Boston, is born. He was brought to the United States when he was five years of age.
The longest running St. Patrick's Day Parade in Canada takes place in Montreal. The 2003 parade was the 179th - the first taking place in 1824.
Thomas Francis Meagher is born. He was one of the leaders of Young Ireland, whose object was to obtain Irish independence by force of arms.
Jane Francesca Wilde known as "Speranza", mother of Oscar Wilde and Irish revolutionary author of the 1840s, is born.
Poet and orator Henry Grattan, the moving force behind the Irish Parliament at College Green before it was dissolved by the Act of Union, dies.
Henry Grattan dies in London. He is buried in Westminster Abbey. His statue is in the outer lobby of the Houses of Parliament at Westminster.
William Drennan, a founder of the United Irishmen, dies. He left instructions that his coffin was to be carried by six Catholics and six Protestants.
William Sadler makes the first balloon crossing of the Irish Sea. He flew from Portobello Barracks, Rathmines, to Anglesey, Wales, in six hours.
Playwright and politician Richard Brinsley Sheridan dies in great poverty. In 1813 he had been arrested for debt!
Robert Hobart, 4th Earl of Buckinghamshire, former MP for Portarlington and Armagh, dies from a fall from his horse in St James's Park, London.
Charles Bianconi, opens his first horse-drawn coach service, between Clonmel and Cahir, Co. Tipperary, a distance of 10 miles.
Thomas Osborne Davis, the Poet Laureate of the Young Ireland party and one of its founders, is born in Mallow, County Cork.
Aubrey Thomas De Vere, poet and critic, is born. Nothing perhaps did more to help the Celtic revival than his tender insight into the Irish character.
Dr. David Livingstone, the famous Scottish missionary and explorer, is born. Livingstone became well-known for his exploration of Africa.
Rebel leader Michael Dwyer, whose guerrilla attacks had maddened British colonial authorities since 1798, surrender.
Robert Emmet, Irish nationalist rebel leader, is executed by hanging and beheading in Thomas Street, Dublin.
James Napper Tandy, Irish patriot, dies in exile in France. He aided Theobald Wolfe Tone in founding the Dublin branch of the United Irishmen.
James Napper Tandy, popular hero memorialized in the Irish ballad The Wearing of the Green, dies in France.
Daniel O'Connell secretly marries his third cousin, Mary O'Connell. Their marriage was happy and eleven children were born to them.
The Act of Union merges the Kingdom of Ireland and the Kingdom of Great Britain to create the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
Theobald Wolfe Tone dies from the wound he recieved from slitting his own throat with a penknife five days earlier in his prison cell in Dublin.
Leader of the '98 rising, Theobald Wolfe Tone, is arrested at Lough Swilley, Co. Donegal, aboard a captured French vessel.
William Hume, MP for Co. Wicklow and a captain in the Hackettstown infantry, is killed in an engagement with Joseph Holt's banditti.
James Napper Tandy, founding member of the Society of United Irishmen, arrive at the isle of Aranmore, off the coast of County Donegal.
Henry Joy McCracken is court-martialled and hanged at Corn Market, Belfast, after refusing to testify against other United Irishmen leaders.
A meeting of the Society of United Irishmen is held in Templepatrick where Henry Joy McCracken is elected general for Antrim.
Edmund Burke, one of the most famous political thinkers of the 18th century, dies in London, one year before Ireland erupted in revolution.
The first Archbishop of New York, John "Dagger" Joseph Hughes, is born in Annaloghan, County Tyrone. His family emigrated to America in 1817.
The French fleet at Bantry Bay is scuppered, thus preventing what might have been an Irish/French victory over the English.
Robert Burns, Scotland's national poet, dies. The Burns Cottage Museum houses the most important collection of Burns manuscripts and artefacts.
The acclaimed poet Robert Burns dies in Dumfries. Burns was aged only 37 and the apparant cause of death was heart failure.
Poet James Macpherson dies. He was the author of The Works of Ossian, Fingal and Temora. He was accused of composing the alleged translations himself.
The Orange Order, more correctly the Loyal Orange Institution of Ireland, comes into existence after the Battle of the Diamond, near Loughgall.
Robert Liston, the first surgeon to use general anaesthetic, is born in Linlithgow, West Lothian, Scotland.
William Jackson, agent of the French revolutionary government, is arrested in Dublin. Betrayed for thirty pieces of silver by a man named Cockayne.
Archibald Hamilton Rowan, United Irishman, is tried on charge of distributing seditious paper and sentenced to two years in prison and fined £500.
The Belfast Harpers Assembly, a gathering of some ten Irish harpers and one Welsh begins in Belfast. The objective is to collect the remaining fragments of the tradition.
Henry Flood dies in Kilkenny. He was founder of the movement which forced Britain to grant legislative independence to Ireland.
The first convicts from Ireland arrive in New South Wales. Between 1791 and 1853, Australia received approximately 26,500 convicts from Ireland.
James Napper Tandy, holds the first meeting of Dublin's United Irishmen, which becomes the center of the movement.
The Society of United Irishmen is founded in Belfast by Theobald Wolfe Tone, Henry Joy McCracken, Thomas Russell and Samuel Neilson.
Demonstrations are held in Dublin, Belfast and elsewhere to commemorate the fall of the Bastille in 1789.
Economist Adam Smith, author of the work An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of The Wealth of Nations, dies.
The Irish mail coach, established by scotsman John Anderson, makes its first run from Dublin to Waterford.
Theobald Wolfe Tone first makes acquaintance of Thomas Russell in public gallery of the House of Commons.
Flora MacDonald, the Jacobite heroine, dies. She is famous for helping Bonnie Prince Charlie escape from Scotland.
Work begins on the construction of the Royal Canal. The canal connects Dublin to the Shannon River and was completed in 1817.
Henry Cooke, considered to be one of the fathers of the Presbyterian Church, is born at Grillagh, near Maghera, Co Derry/Londonderry.
Mary Aikenhead, founder of the Irish Sisters of Charity, is born in Cork. She directed her sisters in their heroic work during the plague of 1832.
Richard Crosbie ascends in a hot-air balloon from Ranelagh Gardens, Dublin, and lands on Clontarf Strand.
The Bank of Ireland, established in Dublin, issues its first notes and opens to the public on this date. The Irish pound is worth £12/13 sterling.
The Knights of St Patrick are founded. It was to be similar in structure to the Order of the Garter in England and the Scottish Order of the Thistle.
John Beresford is appointed Chief Commissioner of Revenue. He ia responsible for bringing architect James Gandon to Dublin to design the Custom House.
The first edition of Robert Burns' poems, the Kilmarnock Edition, is published under the title of "Poems, Chiefly in the Scottish Dialect".
Henry Grattan moves resolutions in favour of legislative independence in the Irish House of Commons.
Catherine McAuley, the first Sister of Mercy, is born in Drumcondra. She could have given her wealth to the poor. Instead she gave her life.
Robert Emmet, Irish nationalist rebel leader and a founding member of the Society of United Irishmen, is born in Dublin.
David Hume, the Scottish philosopher, economist and author, dies. One of the most influential figures in British philosophy of the Eighteenth Century.
Daniel O'Connell, politician, is born in Cahirciveen, Co Kerry. The O'Connell family were members of the Irish Catholic aristocracy in Ireland.
John Hely-Hutchinson, Provost of Trinity College, fights a duel with William Doyle over abusive newspaper articles. Neither party is injured.
Irish politician and Provost of Trinity College, Francis Andrews, dies. On his death he left £3,000 to found the Andrews chair of astronomy at Trinity and the Dunsink Observatory.
Irish writer and physician Oliver Goldsmith dies in London. He is probably best known for his novel The Vicar of Wakefield (1766).
Sir Walter Scott, poet and novelist, is born. His poem The Lay of the Last Minstrel brought him instant fame.
The Octennial Act is passed, which limits Irish Parliaments life to eight years. Before this, it had usually lasted during the life of the sovereign.
Henry Joy McCracken, founding member of the Society of United Irishmen, is born in Belfast. McCracken was executed in 1798.
Four pirates are executed in St Stephen's Green after being found guilty of murdering the high seas Captain Cochrane, Captain Glass and others.
Lord Edward FitzGerald, military leader of the United Irishmen, is born in Carton House, County Kildare.
Theobald Wolfe Tone, a leading figure in the Irish independence movement, is born. He was one of the founders of the society of the United Irishmen.
Francis Andrews, who was also a member of parliament, is appointed first professor of history at the University of Dublin.
The largest St. Patrick's Day Parade in the world is in New York. The parade dates back to 1762. In 2003 more than 150,000 marchers participated.
Robert Burns, Scotlands national bard, is born in Alloway, Ayrshire. In 1786 he published 612 copies of Poems, Chiefly in the Scottish Dialect.
Philosopher George Berkeley dies suddenly while listening to his wife reading from the Bible. He is buried in the nave at Christ Church, Oxford.
Playwright and politician, Richard Brinsley Sheridan, is born in Dublin. As a politician, Sheridan opposed the Act of Union with Ireland.
James Thomson, the Scottish poet, dies. His most famous works include the anthem Rule, Britannia!.
Prince Charles Edward Stewart, Bonnie Prince Charlie, lands in Eriskay. The last Jacobite rising was to follow.
Henry Grattan, member of the Irish House of Commons and campaigner for legislative freedom for the Irish Parliament in the late 18th century, is born.
Flora MacDonald and Bonnie Prince Charlie set sail from Benbecula to Skye. She helped him escape to Skye by disguising him as her Irish maid.
Charles Edward Stuart (Bonnie Prince Charlie) enters Derby during the '45 Jacobite rising, attempting to restore the Stuart dynasty.
Irish writer Jonathan Swift, the author of classic works like Gulliver's Travels (1726), dies in Dublin at the age of 78.
The first golf club in the world is founded in Edinburgh. The Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers hold their first meeting on Leith Links.
Turlough O'Carolan, the blind Irish harper and composer, dies at the home of his patron Mrs MacDermot Roe in Alderford, County Roscommon.
The Belfast Newsletter is launched, now the oldest surviving newspaper in Ireland or Britain, and one of the oldest in the world.
The first civic and public celebrations of Saint Patrick's Day takes place in Boston, Massachusetts. All arranged by the Charitable Irish Society.
Birth of Scottish poet and the author of, among others, The Works of Ossian and Fingal, James Macpherson.
Irish writer Oliver Goldsmith is born. He is the author of The Vicar of Wakefield, "The Good-natur'd Man" and "She Stoops to Conquer".
Sir Arthur Guinness is born in Celbridge, Co. Kildare. He founded the Guinness company, famous for it's stout and book of records, in 1759.
The first number of George Faulkner's Dublin Journal is published. It was published until April 1825, when it was incorporated into The Irish Times.
Thomas Burgh and Richard Stewart receive the first £2,000 of £8,000 from the Irish parliament for operating their colliery at Ballycastle, Co Antrim.
James Cotter is executed for high treason in supporting the Jacobite cause. His son, Sir James Cotter, will later be MP for Askeaton.
The Declaratory Act defines the right of British Parliament to legislate for Ireland, and denies appelate jurisdiction of Irish House of Lords.
The Old Pretender’s Jacobite army disbands at Aberdeen, ending the 1715 uprising. Thirty years later his son, Charles, would try again.
A force of Jacobites led by the Earl of Mar, fights an inconclusive battle against a Hanoverian force led the 2nd Duke of Argyll, at Sheriffmuir.
Birth of Nahum Tate the first Irish-born Poet Laureate of England. His best known work is While Shepherds Watched Their Flocks By Night.
William Molyneux (born 1699), son of Sir Thomas Molyneux, a former MP, is killed when a leaden image falls on him in a garden near Dublin.
The Linen Board meets for the first time. It had been established to help promote the linen industry, at times supporting every branch of the trade.
Scottish poet and playwright James Thomson is born in Ednam in Roxburghshire. He is known for the lyrics of Rule, Britannia!
Richard Levinge, an Irish MP, is committed to the Tower of London for speaking ill of his fellow Commissioners of Forfeited Estates.
Penal laws are passed which restrict the rights of Catholics to have an education, to bear arms, or to possess a horse worth more than five pounds.
Irish soldier and leader Patrick Sarsfield dies. In 1691 he had marched his men out of Limerick, following the fall of the city, and sailed to France.
A Royalist force, under the command of Captain Robert Campbell of Glenlyon, carries out a massacre of of 38 MacDonalds at Glencoe.
Treaty of Limerick is signed by Godert de Ginkell and Patrick Sarsfield, ending the Williamite War in Ireland. The treaty allows evacuation of the Irish army to France.
A Jacobite force under Patrick Sarsfield, guided by Galloping Hogan, destroys a Williamite siege train at Ballyneety, hampering the Siege of Limerick.
Charles Chalmont, Marquis de Saint-Ruth, a French general arrives in Ireland after being sent by Louis XIV to command the Irish army.
The victory of Protestant King William of Orange over Catholic King James in the Battle of the Boyne.
William of Orange defeats the forces of James II, supported by the French, at the Battle of the Boyne.
William of Orange, William III, lands at Carrickfergus to begin his march south to meet James II's army at the River Boyne, in Co. Meath.
One of William III's most senior commanders, the Duke of Schomberg, bring twelve regiments of foot ashore at Ballyholme Bay in County Down.
Derry/Londonderry declares allegiance to William III, Prince of Orange, on arrival of the "deliverance from popery and slavery".
James II lands at Kinsale with French troops and munitions. To James, Ireland was the starting point from which he could regain the throne in England.
William (William of Orange) and Mary (daughter of James II), are proclaimed king and queen. They were also first cousins, grandchildren of Charles I.
William of Orange arrives in England, urged by the English Parliament to save England from a Catholic takeover.
James Edward Stuart, "the Old Pretender", is born. James was the son of King James VII, who was dethroned due to the Glorious Revolution.
The second Declaration of Indulgence, issued by James II, suspends penal laws against Catholics and dissenters.
The Earl of Tyrconnell becomes Lord Deputy of Ireland and creates an overwhelmingly Catholic army, judiciary and civil administration.
With the return of a Catholic monarchy, James II, payments to the Catholic hierarchy are authorized. Catholics are appointed to government positions.
Philosopher George Berkeley is born the eldest son to William Berkeley, an officer of customs, near Kilkenny in Ireland.
James II ascend to the throne. He openly opposed the Test Act of 1673 that barred all Catholics and Dissenters from holding administrative positions.
