Charles II dies and James VII is crowned. James's Catholicism created a revival of the religious conflicts that had plagued the previous century.
Charles II issues the Declaration of Indulgence, suspending all penal laws against Catholics and Dissenters.
Irish novelist Jonathan Swift is born (after his father's death) by English parents. He's the author of such works as Gulliver's Travels.
Queen Anne, last of the Stuart monarchs, is born. In 1707, she presided over the union of the parliaments of Scotland and England.
Commissioners are appointed to allot the land of Oliver Cromwell's Connacht plantation to transplanted Irish.
Oliver Cromwell becomes the Lord Protector, i. e. a virtual dictator, of the Common Wealth (England, Scotland and Ireland).
The Barebone's Parliament, an assembly called by Oliver Cromwell, starts. Ireland and Scotland are represented by six and five members respectively.
Sir Phelim O'Neill is executed by Parliament forces in Dublin, having refused to state that Charles I had authorized the 1641 rebellion.
The coronation of Charles II take place at Scone. This was to be the last occasion a monarch was crowned in Scotland.
Cromwell abandons the Siege of Waterford, due to sickness rife in the Parliamentarian army, and retires to winter quarters at Youghall.
Cromwell's army storms Wexford and massacres 2000 people. Helped by the treason of one Captain Stafford, who gave Cromwell entrance to the town.
Oliver Cromwell arrives in Ireland as Commander-in-Chief and Lord Lieutenant with an army of 20,000, a huge artillery train and a large navy.
In desperation, the Confederates signs a truce with the Earl of Inchiquin, who had switched sides to the royalists.
Lord Inchiquin, a royalist turned Parliamentarian, sacks the Irish Catholic Confederate garrison at the Rock of Cashel.
The Battle of Benburb, in which Owen Roe O'Neill's troops crushed the parliamentarian forces of Robert Monro, takes place in Co. Tyrone.
The Marquis of Ormond, James Butler, leads the King's forces against the Confederates, defeating Lord Mountgarret at the Battle of Kilrush.
The English parliament passes the Adventurers' Act, which declare the lands of leading rebels forfeit and offer them for sale to English subscribers.
Catholics, under Phelim O'Neill, rise against the Protestants and massacre men, women and children to the number of 40,000 (some say 100,000).
40 years after the great rebellion of Hugh O'Neill, earl of Tyrone, the Irish rise in revolt, first in Ulster, then later in the rest of Ireland.
Patrick D'Arcy, a prominent constitutional lawyer, argues at a conference held in the dining-room of Dublin Castle that the Irish parliament possesses independent authority.
John Atherton, Bishop of Waterford and Lismore, and his lover and tithe proctor John Child are convicted of buggery and hanged.
Thomas Wentworth forces Ulster Scots over the age of 16 to take an Oath of Abjuration (Black Oath) binding their allegiance to the king.
The Second Covenant is signed in Greyfriars Churchyard. The document was a response to Charles I's attempts to introduce a Book of Common Prayer.
Patents are granted for plantations in parts of Leitrim, King's County, Queen's County and Westmeath.
Hugh O'Neill dies in Rome. He had led an unsuccessful uprising against the English, and was forced into exile as part of the Flight of Earls.
Derry is formally renamed Londonderry with the granting of a new royal charter by James I, during the British Plantation of Ulster.
Hugh O'Neill, Ruari O'Donnell and other chiefs depart Lough Swilly for the continent in what has become known as the Flight of the Earls.
After a long battle against English rule, Hugh O'Neill, the Earl of Tyrone submits to Lord Mountjoy, Charles Blount, at Mellifont.
King James VI of Scotland is proclaimed King James I of England. He acceded to the English throne on the death of Queen Elizabeth I.
Red Hugh O'Donnell dies in Spain. The British had sent an agent to poison him. Some say he succeeded, others say O'Donnell died of natural causes.
Donal Cam O'Sullivan sets out from Glengarriff with 1,000 followers to seek sanctuary in Ulster. 15 days later, 35 survivors find it in Leitrim.
Red Hugh O'Donnell leaves for Spain, and Hugh O'Neill withdraws to Ulster, after being heavily defeated by Mountjoy at Kinsale on Christmas Eve.
Hugh O'Neill and Red Hugh O'Donnell are heavily defeated by Lord Mountjoy at the Battle of Kinsale on Christmas Eve.
Hugh O'Neill engages Lord Mountjoy's forces of 3,000 foot and 300 horsemen in the Battle of Moyry Pass. Moyry is in Co. Armagh.
Charles Blount (8th Lord Mountjoy) becomes Lord Deputy of Ireland. His victory at Kinsale in 1601 led to the conquest of Ireland by English forces.
The Battle of the Yellow Ford is regarded by many as the most disastrous defeat the English ever suffered at the hands of the Irish.
The great-great-grandmother of Sir Patrick Dun (physician, member of the Irish parliament 1692-1713) is burned as a witch at Aberdeen.
Mary, Queen of Scots is beheaded at Fotheringay Castle after being imprisoned in England for the best part of twenty years.
One of the leading, and certainly the most famous, reformers of Church of Scotland, John Knox, dies.
Mary, Queen of Scots is forced to abdicate the throne, leaving her infant son James as monarch and her half-brother Moray as Regent.
Mary, Queen of Scots, is imprisoned in Loch Leven castle. Mary was imprisoned after the defeat of her forces at the Battle of Carberry Hill.
King James VI is born. He acceded to the throne of Scotland at the age of one, after his mother, Mary, Queen of Scots, was forced to abdicate.
Mary of Guise, Regent of Scotland, dies. Mary was the wife of King James V and the mother of Mary, Queen of Scots.
Mary Stuart, is born at Linlithge Palace. She was Queen of Scotland from the year 1542 to the year 1567.
Gerald Fitzgerald, Henry VII's Lord Deputy and 8th Earl of Kildare, is arrested in Dublin. On 5 March he is sent to England and put in the Tower.
Edward Poynings, best known for his introduction of Poynings' Law, is appointed Lord Deputy of Ireland.
The Earl of Kildare establishes the Brotherhood of St George as a defence force for the Pale, with 120 mounted archers, 40 horsemen and 40 pages.
Orkney and Shetland become part of Scotland. They were provided as security for the dowry of Princess Margaret by the King of Norway and Denmark.
The Irish parliament at Drogheda declares that Ireland is bound only by laws accepted by its own parliament and English writs are invalid.
Richard II returns to Ireland and wages war in Leinster. Art MacMurrough refuses to submit, claiming to be the rightful King of Ireland.
Philip de Courtenay, Lord Deputy of Ireland, lands at Dalkey and campaigns in the midlands and the Leinster mountains.
Gerald Fitzmaurice, 3rd earl of Desmond and son of Maurice Fitzthomas, first earl of Desmond, is appointed justiciar (viceroy) of Ireland.
William de Burgh, earl of Ulster, is assassinated by his own knights, John de Logan and two of the de Mandevilles, at Le Ford, Belfast.
Edward Bruce's army reaches Castleknock. He had come to Ireland with the aim to create a kingdom and drive out the Norman-Irish settlers.
The Scottish army, under Robert (the Bruce) I, defeats the English army at the Battle of Bannockburn.
Sir William Wallace is executed. He was captured and became one of the first persons to endure the agonies of being hanged, drawn and quartered.
King Edward I removes to England the Stone of Destiny on which generations of Scottish kings has been crowned.
Scottish Coronation Stone, the Stone of Destiny, is removed from Scone Abbey. It wasn't to be returned until 1996.
Scotland established as one when a woman could propose marriage to a man! If he refused, he was required to pay a fine.
Robert the Bruce is born in Turnberry Castle, Ayrshire. Bruce would later lead the campaign to regain Scottish independence..
The Norman-Irish under the justiciar William de Dene are heavily defeated by Fineen MacCarthy at the Battle of Callann in Co. Kerry.
Brian O'Neill, the King of Tyrone, is defeated and killed by the Norman-Irish and their Gaelic Irish allies at the Battle of Down.
Cathal Crobhdearg Ua Conchobair, king of Connacht, dies at the age of 72. This finally opens the way for the Norman occupation of Connacht.
Archbishop Henry of London replaces Geoffrey de Marisco as justiciar of Ireland. De Marisco was accused of financial irregularities and had to resign.
John Comyn, first Anglo-Norman Archbishop of Dublin, dies and is buried in Christ Church Cathedral. He had founded St Patrick's Cathedral in 1191.
Henry II's son John lands at Waterford to assert control over Hugh de Lacy, but he fails. Henry suspects that de Lacy wants to be king of Ireland.
Henry II returns to Britain after having granted a charter to Dublin, the first granted to an Irish town. He will never return to Ireland.
Strongbow, henchman of Henry II, arrive in Waterford at the behest of Dermot McMurrough, an event described as the beginning of the woes of Ireland.
The Dublin Norse and the King of Leinster, with Viking allies from overseas, are defeated by Brian Boru's army at Clontarf. Brian is killed.
It is believed that Ireland's patron saint, Patrick, died on the 17th of March in the year 461. Mythology credits him with banishing snakes from the island of Ireland.
Patrick was not the first Christian missionary to Ireland, but he seems to have been the one who made the most impact. HAPPY ST. PATRICK'S DAY!
Saint Patrick is the patron saint of Ireland. He was born around 385 in Caledonia, probably at Kilpatrick. His parents were Romans living in Britain.
English folk singer Louis Killen is born. He formed one of Britain's first folk clubs in 1958 in Newcastle upon Tyne and became a professional folk singer in 1961.
Louisa Jo Killen (né Louis Killen) dies. She worked with people like Pete Seeger and The Clancy Brothers. A few years before her death she underwent a gender reassignment to become Louisa Jo.
Ronnie Browne, the Scottish folk musician and founding member of The Corries, is born in Edinburgh.
The Scottish historical novelist, playwright, and poet Sir Walter Scott dies at the age of 61. Famous works by him include Ivanhoe, Rob Roy and The Lady of the Lake.
The first Archbishop of New York, John Joseph "Dagger" Hughes, dies in New York at the age of 66.
Irish writer Oliver St. John Gogarty dies in New York City at the age of 79. He is the model for the 'stately, plump Buck Mulligan' in James Joyce's Ulysses.
John Keegan 'Leo' Casey, the Poet of the Fenians, dies at the age of 23. He is buried in Glasnevin Cemetery in Dublin.
The Scottish philosopher David Hume, known especially for his philosophical empiricism and scepticism, is born in Edinburgh.
A car bomb in Omagh, Co Tyrone, kills 29 and injures about 220 innocent people. Carried out by the Real IRA who opposed the IRA's ceasefire and the Good Friday Agreement.
The Irish writer and painter Christy Brown is born in Crumlin, Dublin. His most recognised work is his autobiography; titled My Left Foot.
Irish Independence Party member and Larne Borough Council councillor John Turnley is murdered by the Ulster Defence Association as he drive to attend a political meeting.
The Earl of Sussex, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, proclaims Shane O'Neill a traitor and begins a campaign against him which continues until 1567.
The Synod of Kilkenny regulates discipline and practice in the Catholic Province of Dublin.
The founder of public transportation in Ireland, Charles Bianconi, is born in Costa Masnaga, Italy.
The founder of public transportation in Ireland, at a time preceding railways, Charles Bianconi, dies at Longfield House, Boherlahan, County Tipperary.
Irish singer, guitarist, composer and producer Mícheál Ó Domhnaill is born. He was a major influence on Irish traditional music in the second half of the twentieth century.
William Henry Grattan Flood, Irish author, composer, musicologist, and historian is born in Lismore, Co Waterford.
William Henry Grattan Flood, Irish author, composer, musicologist, and historian dies in Enniscorthy, Co Wexford.
Robert Emmet is tried for treason and Chief Justice Lord Norbury's sentence him to be hanged, drawn and quartered.
Edward Carson, the Irish unionist politician, barrister and judge, is born in Dublin. He was leader of the Irish Unionist Alliance and Ulster Unionist Party between 1910 and 1921.
Edward Carson, the Irish unionist politician, barrister and judge, dies. He was leader of the Irish Unionist Alliance and Ulster Unionist Party between 1910 and 1921.
Seán Ó Riada, leader of Ceoltóirí Chualann and influential figure in the revival of Irish traditional music during the 1960s, is born.
Lennox Robinson, playwright and theatrical producer, dies. He was a leading figure in the later stages of the Irish literary renaissance.
Joseph Holt, guerilla leadear in the Wicklow Mountains and United Irishman, dies at Kingstown now Dún Laoghaire near Dublin.
Over 15,000 British soldiers launch an attack on Vinegar Hill outside Enniscorthy, County Wexford, the largest camp and headquarters of the Wexford United Irish rebels.
Samuel Neilson one of the founder members of the Society of United Irishmen and the founder of its newspaper the Northern Star is born in Ballyroney, Co Down.
Samuel Neilson one of the founder members of the Society of United Irishmen dies suddenly of a stroke in New York.
Thomas Russell, a co-founder and leader of the United Irishmen is executed for his part in Robert Emmet's rebellion.
Thomas Russell, co-founder and leader of the United Irishmen is born in Dromahane, Co Cork to an Anglican family.
Hugh Alan "Buddy" MacMaster, one of the most renowned artists in the tradition of Cape Breton fiddle music, dies at his home in Judique, Nova Scotia
The Irish Free State is established as a Dominion of the British Commonwealth of Nations under the Anglo-Irish Treaty.
Tim Healy, politician, journalist, author, barrister and the first Governor-General of the Irish Free State, is born in Bantry, Co Cork.
Tim Healy, politician, journalist, author, barrister and the first Governor-General of the Irish Free State, dies aged 75 in Chapelizod, Co Dublin.
Irish American stepdancer, choreographer and musician Michael Flatley is born in Chicago.
Michael Flatley and co performs the original Riverdance as the intermission act in the Eurovision Song Contest.
Composer and conductor Michael William Balfe is born in Dublin. He is best known for his opera The Bohemian Girl.
Ewan MacColl, owing to his political views, rather than being discharged, is declared a deserter from the British Army.
Jim McCann, singer and guitar player, dies at the age of 70. He had been battling throat cancer for some time. Jim was a member of The Dubliners between 1974 and 1979.
Robert Liston, the first surgeon to use general anaesthetic, dies in London at the age of 53.
Fiddler James Morrison, known as "The Professor", is born near Riverstown, County Sligo at the townland of Drumfin.
Actor Michael Gambon is born in Cabra, Dublin. He is known from television series like The Singing Detective and Maigret, and six Harry Potter films.
Birth of William Thomas Cosgrave. He served as the first President of the Executive Council (prime minister) of the Irish Free State from 1922 to 1932.
Justin McCarthy, Irish nationalist and Liberal historian, novelist and politician, dies in Folkestone, Kent, England.
Michael Cusack, Irish teacher and founder of the Gaelic Athletic Association, is born in the parish of Carran, County Clare.
Sonny Brogan, one of the earliest advocates of the two-row B/C button accordion in traditional music, is born in Dublin.
Sonny Brogan, one of the earliest advocates of the two-row B/C button accordion in traditional music, dies.
Patrick Hillery, the sixth President of Ireland from 1976 until 1990, is born in Spanish Point, County Clare. He was first elected to Dáil Éireann in 1951.
Patrick Hillery, the sixth President of Ireland from 1976 until 1990, dies in his Dublin home following a short illness.
Former member of The Dubliners, Bobby Lynch, dies. Lynch played the acoustic guitar and sang. He left the band in 1965 when Luke Kelly returned later that year.
Former member of The Dubliners, Bob Lynch, is born. He played the acoustic guitar and sang. He left the band in 1965 when Luke Kelly returned later that year.
The Pogues re-release their 1987 Christmas classic Fairytale of New York, which goes straight in at No. 3 in the UK Singles charts on Christmas Day 2005.
Former Pogues and Radiators member Philip Chevron dies in Dublin, Ireland from oesophageal cancer at age 56.
We wish you a Merry Christmas!
Jane Francesca Wilde known as "Speranza", mother of Oscar Wilde and Irish revolutionary author of the 1840s, dies in London.
We wish you a really Happy New Year!
Poet and playwright Padraic Fallon dies. His verse plays, Diarmuid and Grainne and The Vision of Mac Conglinne, were produced on Radio Éireann.
Hugh O'Brien, the first Catholic Irish-born mayor of Boston, dies. He was brought to the United States when he was five years of age.
Irish actor and comedian Jimmy O'Dea is born in Dublin. Together with Harry O'Donovan he created his most famous character - Biddy Mulligan.

Irish comedy scriptwriter, stage manager and actor Harry O'Donovan dies. He formed a famous partnership with comedian Jimmy O'Dea and together they created O'Dea's most famous character, Biddy Mulligan.
Aubrey Thomas De Vere, poet and critic, dies. Nothing perhaps did more to help the Celtic revival than his tender insight into the Irish character.
Martin "Junior" Crehan dies. He is a legendary fiddler, concertina player, singer and composer of tunes.
Mary Aikenhead, founder of the Irish Sisters of Charity, dies in Dublin aged 71. She directed her sisters in their heroic work during the plague of 1832.
William O'Brien, politician, journalist, agrarian agitator, social revolutionary, Irish nationalist and founder of the United Irish League, is born in Mallow, County Cork.
William O'Brien, politician, journalist, agrarian agitator, social revolutionary, Irish nationalist and founder of the United Irish League, dies suddenly while on a visit to London.
Seán MacBride, IRA leader, politician, head of Amnesty International, recipient of Nobel and Lenin peace prizes, dies in Dublin. He is buried in Glasnevin Cemetery.
Mother Mary Martin, founder of the Medical Missionaries of Mary, is born in Glenageary, County Dublin. The Medical Missionaries of Mary first came to America in 1950.
Archibald Hamilton Rowan a founding member of The Dublin Society of United Irishmen is born in London. Despite his wealth and privilege, he was a strong advocate for Irish liberty.
Archibald Hamilton Rowan a founding member of The Dublin Society of United Irishmen dies. Despite his wealth and privilege, he was a strong advocate for Irish liberty.
Mary Robinson, the first female President of Ireland, is born in Ballina, County Mayo. She fought for bills to fully liberalise availability of contraceptives and decriminalising homosexuality.
Mary Robinson is inaugurated as the seventh, and first female, President of Ireland. She fought for bills to fully liberalise availability of contraceptives and decriminalising homosexuality.
Mary Robinson resign as President of Ireland. She resigns in order to take up appointment as United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.
Countess Markievicz dies of complications related to appendicitis.. As a revolutionary she fought for equal rights for women as well as the Irish Republic.
John Redmond, Irish nationalist politician and leader of the Irish Parliamentary Party from 1900 to 1918, is born in Kilrane, County Wexford.
John Redmond, Irish nationalist politician and leader of the Irish Parliamentary Party from 1900 to 1918, dies at a London nursing home.
Danny Blanchflower dies in London. Capped 56 times for Northern Ireland, he was captain when they reached the quarter-finals of the World Cup in 1958.
Sean O'Casey's play The Plough and The Stars is performed for the first time at the Abbey Theatre in the writer's native Dublin.
Thomas J Kelly, Irish revolutionary and leader of the Irish Republican Brotherhood, is born in Mountbellew, County Galway.
Thomas J Kelly, Irish revolutionary and leader of the Irish Republican Brotherhood, dies at his residence in New York.
Thomas Burgh dies. He designed a number of the large public buildings of Dublin including the old Custom House and the Linen Hall.
Packie Russell dies. He was a well known Irish traditional concertina player and storyteller out of Doolin, County Clare.
Micho Russell is born in Doonagore, Doolin, County Clare. He was an Irish musician and author best known for his expert tin whistle performance.
Gussie Russell dies in Ennistymon, County Clare. He earned fame as a traditional musician, together with his brothers Micho and Packie.
Fiddler Jerry Holland dies at the age of 54. He gained an appreciation for his traditional style of Cape Breton fiddle music.
Paul Cullen, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Dublin and previously of Armagh, and the first Irish cardinal, is born in Narraghmore, Athy, County Kildare.
Paul Cullen, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Dublin and previously of Armagh, and the first Irish cardinal, dies in Dublin.
Bobby Sands, leader of the 1981 hunger strike, is born in Whiteabbey, Newtownabbey, County Antrim.
James Stephens, Irish Republican and the founding member of the Irish Republican Brotherhood, is born in Kilkenny.
James Stephens, Irish Republican and the founding member of the Irish Republican Brotherhood, dies. He is buried in Glasnevin cemetery, Dublin.
Irish born Cedric Gibbons dies in Los Angeles. He was the designer of the coveted Oscar statuette and winner of eleven Academy Awards himself.
Ireland's RTÉ News reports the launch of Fur TV, a new TV channel aimed specifically at pets.
Charlie Piggott, Irish traditional musician and a founding member of De Dannan, is born.
Paddy Keenan, Irish player of the uilleann pipes and a founding member of The Bothy Band, is born in Trim, County Meath.
Paddy Glackin, Irish fiddler and founding member of The Bothy Band, is born in Clontarf, Dublin. He is considered one of Ireland's leading traditional fiddle players.
Irish folk musician, songwriter and record producer Dónal Lunny is born in Tullamore. He was a founding member of Planxty and The Bothy Band.
The Edict of Expulsion is issued expelling all Jews from England and Ireland by 1 November.
Walter de Burgh, 2nd Lord of Connaught and 1st Earl of Ulster, dies.
The earliest known Irish Parliament meet at Castledermot, Co Kildare.
Edward Bruce and his fleet lands on the Irish coast between Olderfleet Castle at Larne, and Glendrum to mark the beginning of the Bruce campaign in Ireland.
Irish country music singer Larry Cunningham, one of the leading figures of the showband scene in the 1960s and 1970s, is born.
Irish country music singer Larry Cunningham, one of the leading figures of the showband scene in the 1960s and 1970s, dies.
Show jumper Eddie Macken is born in Granard, Co Longford. He represented Ireland at the Olympic Games in 1992, 1996 and as team trainer in 2004.
The Second Battle of Athenry. The battle was a devastating defeat for the Connacht Gaels, who were allied with the Scotsman Edward Bruce.
The Battle of Dysert O'Dea near Corofin, Co Clare. Richard de Clare is defeated and killed by Conchobhar Ó Deághaidh in alliance with O'Connors, O'Briens, MacNamaras and Ó hEithirs.
Alexander de Bicknor, best known to history as the Archbishop of Dublin from 1317 until his death in 1349, arrives in Ireland.
The Battle of Faughart is fought between a Hiberno-Norman force led by John de Bermingham and Edmund Butler against a Scots-Irish army commanded by Edward Bruce.
Petronilla de Meath, maidservant of Dame Alice Kyteler, is the first known case in Ireland's history of burning at the stake for the crime of heresy.
Richard Óg de Burgh, 2nd Earl of Ulster, one of the most powerful Irish nobles of the late 13th and early 14th centuries, dies at Athassel Priory, near Cashel, Co Tipperary.
Maol Ruanaidh Cam Ó Cearbhaill, Irish harpist and player of the tiompan, is murdered with many others at the Braganstown Massacre.
James Butler, 2nd Earl of Ormond, Lord Justice of Ireland and a dominant political leader in Ireland in the 1360s and 1370s, is born in Kilkenny.
James Butler, 2nd Earl of Ormond, Lord Justice of Ireland and a dominant political leader in Ireland in the 1360s and 1370s, dies in his castle of Knocktopher.
Maurice FitzGerald, 1st Earl of Desmond, an Irish nobleman in the Peerage of Ireland, Captain of Desmond Castle in Kinsale, dies at Dublin Castle.
James Butler, 1st Earl of Ormond, dies and is buried in St. Mary's Collegiate Church Gowran, Gowran, Co Kilkenny.
Alexander de Bicknor, best known to history as the Archbishop of Dublin from 1317 until his death in 1349, dies.
Elizabeth de Burgh, the second wife and the only queen consort of King Robert the Bruce, dies at the royal residence at Cullen, Banffshire.
King Richard II of England leads his first expedition to Ireland to enforce his rule.
King Richard II of England defines the borders of English rule in Ireland, later to become known as the English Pale.
James Butler, 4th Earl of Ormond, is born in Kilkenny. He was called 'The White Earl' and esteemed for his learning.
James Butler, 4th Earl of Ormond, dies in Dublin. He was known as 'The White Earl' and esteemed for his learning.
King Richard II of England leaves Ireland, having achieved his objectives.
King Richard makes Roger Mortimer his Lord Lieutenant of Ireland when he is a child of seven, with his uncle, Sir Thomas Mortimer, acting as his deputy.
Roger de Mortimer, 4th Earl of March and 6th Earl of Ulster, at the age of 24 is slain in a skirmish in County Meath.
Lord Forbes's siege of Galway. A naval squadron of seventeen ships appear in Galway Bay. They have come to relieve the garrison of Forthill at the request of the English Parliament.
The First Battle of Athenry is fought at Athenry. The Gaelic forces of Connacht besieged the town but were repelled by the Normans under Jordan de Exeter, Sheriff of Connacht.
The Battle of Connor is fought in the townland of Tannybrake just over a mile north of what is now the modern village of Connor, Co Antrim. It was part of the Bruce campaign in Ireland.
The Battle of Skerries, also named the Battle of Ardscull, was a battle in the Bruce campaign in Ireland, part of the First War of Scottish Independence, resulting in a Scottish victory.
The Battle of Lough Raska takes place near Corcomroe Abbey in north Co Clare. It was part of a fight for control of the Uí Briain chieftaincy and part of the Anglo-Norman wars in Ireland.
The Battle of Ardnocher is fought between the Normans and the MacGeoghegans of Cenel Fiachaigh or Kenaleagh in modern Co Westmeath. The Norman force is defeated.
The Battle of Knockdoe is fought between two Anglo-Irish lords Gerald FitzGerald, Earl of Kildare, and Ulick Fionn Burke, lord of Clanricarde, along with their respective Irish allies.
Death of Thomas FitzGerald, 10th Earl of Kildare, also known as Silken Thomas, a leading figure in 16th century Irish history.
Thomas FitzGerald, accompanied by 140 armoured gallowglasses, ride to the Council at St. Mary's Abbey, Dublin, and publicly renounce his allegiance to his cousin King Henry VIII.
James Ormond, Lord Treasurer of Ireland from 1492 to 1494, is slain by his rival and kinsman Sir Piers Butler 'in a kind of impromptu duel near Kilkenny'.
Thomas FitzGerald, who was deprived of the earldom of Desmond after he had concluded a marriage to a woman of Gaelic ancestry, dies in Rouen, France.
George Plantagenet, 1st Duke of Clarence, is born in Dublin at a time when his father, the Duke of York, had begun to challenge Henry VI for the crown.
Edmund Oldhall, who was Bishop of Meath and acting Lord Chancellor of Ireland, dies at his official residence Ardbraccan, Co Meath.
Archbishop John Alen is killed by two retainers of "Silken Thomas" Fitzgerald at Artane Castle. Whether Silken Thomas actually ordered the killing or not remains a subject of dispute.
James FitzGerald, 8th Earl of Desmond, is murdered at Rathkeale by John Murtagh, one of his servants, possibly at the instigation of Desmond's brother and successor.
Thaddeus McCarthy is appointed Bishop of Cork and Cloyne.
Thaddeus McCarthy, Bishop of Cork and Cloyne, having presumably walked from Rome, dies in Ivrea, Italy.
The city of Galway is granted a royal charter and mayoralty by Richard III of England.
Tomás Bairéad is appointed Bishop of Annaghdown, Co Galway.
Lambert Simnel is crowned in Christ Church Cathedral in Dublin as "King Edward VI". He is about ten years old.
Sir Edward Poynings assembles the Parliament of Ireland in Drogheda to tell it that it is thereafter to be placed under the authority of the Parliament of England by Poynings' Law.
Rowland FitzEustace, 1st Baron Portlester, Irish peer, statesman and judge, and one of the dominant political figures in late fifteenth-century Ireland, dies.
James Butler, 9th Earl of Ormond, known as "The Lame", dies after having been poisoned at a dinner in London nine days before.
James Butler, 9th Earl of Ormond, along with his steward, James Whyte, and 16 of his household are poisoned while dining at Ely Palace in Holborn.
Arthur Lynch, 22nd Mayor of Galway and a member of one of the Tribes of Galway, drowns in the Corrib when he, in an intoxicated state, falls off the Great West Bridge.
James FitzGerald, 10th Earl of Desmond, dies at Dingle and is buried with his father at Tralee.
